awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Future Directions for Seafloor Geodesy Workshop 2020
awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop will bring together members of the established and emerging scientific community interested in seafloor deformation using geodetic tools deployed on the seafloor.  The workshop will offer the first opportunity to foster communications between scientists and engineers to explore how to utilize existing resources to maximize science goals.  Geodetic instruments can capture motions offshore that give us important insight into earthquakes and submarine volcanic activity.  The workshop is focused on seafloor deformation because ninety percent of Earth's active tectonic plate boundaries are underwater and our ability to measure the deformation that leads up to an earthquake is predominantly on-land, which doesn’t capture most of the seafloor movement. This is particularly important along subduction zones, where tsunamis may be generated by the movement on a fault during an earthquake. The conference will include 90 participants. The timing of the conference is important because a new resource is being developed for the community, a set of seafloor geodetic instruments that can measure precise long-term horizontal and short-term vertical movements.  At the workshop, the community will discuss how to apply these resources to maximize science and accessibility of data, leading to proposals for future offshore projects.  The workshop will broaden participation in the field of seafloor geodesy and a significant number of the participants will be early career scientists. The workshop will offer an opportunity to foster connections between scientists and engineers.


This workshop will bring together and build the seafloor geodesy community, including scientists from academic institutions, government agencies, and international partners focused on understanding scientific and engineering problems associated with measuring deformation on the seafloor.  During the workshop the organizers will address the current status of existing, the development of emerging, and plans for future technologies in the field. As well, the workshop is essential to develop plans for the use of a recently funded pool of GNSS-Acoustic and Bottom Pressure Recorder seafloor geodetic instruments.  The workshop will identify high priority scientific questions and targets for this pool of instruments and the community preferred structure for managing the instrument pool. The community will help identify the highest priority scientific questions and targets addressable with the instrument pool and develop a plan for managing the equipment to effectively answer geophysical questions in earth deformation in the offshore environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project funded two workshops to bring together the community of geophysicists interested in developing an understanding of the ground deformation in underwater regions, encompassing the vast majority of global plate boundaries, and associated geologic hazards (earthquakes, volcanism, landslides, and tsunamis).

The outcomes of the first workshop, titled "Future Directions in Seafloor Geodesy" that was held in 2021, included:

  1. Identified the active community, and their interests in performing experiments and working with seafloor geodesy data and equipment.  The workshop had 165 registrants from 97 universities and research labs, 69 early-career scientists, 10 postdoctoral researchers, and 27 graduate students.  Most participants were from the US, however 20 countries were represented, including Canada, Chile, Germany, Japan, and New Zealand.  
  2. Received community feedback on interests in the usage of the US-funded seafloor geodetic instrument pool usage, including getting input on preferences for community- versus PI-led projects, and the levels of technical support, need for a facility, and data reduction PI or community users would like.  Given the relatively small size of the existing pool given community size, the overwhelming sentiment was that most instrumentation be made available for community experiments, with some left for individual or small-group PI-driven projects.  The community felt that much of the technical ship-board and piloting work remained with trained technical staff, but had a strong interest in the scientists having control over final data processing to improve results, and develop novel applications.
  3. Evaluate possible targets, particularly should community targets dominate discussion. The community were most interested in making new measurements in subduction zone environments which are poorly understood offshore, and are responsible for the world's largest earthquakes and tsunamis.  Regions with primary interest included offshore Alaska (site of a magnitude 9.2 earthquake in 1964), and offshore the Pacific Northwest (Cascadia, a region with a similar record of very large earthquakes, with the last one occurring over 300 years ago). A second interest included underwater volcanic processes, including behavior offshore of Hawaii, and along the Axial seamount, a region already observed to have large submarine deformation events.  Further support included deformation along submarine transform faults, and constraining tectonic plate motion in actively deforming or otherwise under-constrained oceanic plates.
  4. Sought feedback on inclusive and diverse workforce development to grow the community interested in ocean-going seafloor geodetic research. The community felt five items were most important: data access, undergraduate engagement, diversity, coordination, and networking opportunities.  Data access should include straight-forward mechanisms to find, extract and work with data in a reliable way.  Processing tools should be developed, specifically for GNSS-Acoustic methods, that allow for a larger community to reduce and understand data.  To develop the pipeline of researchers, undergraduates need to be informed and potentially be given datasets to work with seafloor data. We need to strive to engage minority and indigenous populations, including through projects that incorporate minority-serving institutions, and participation with community colleges. Coordination through community experiments, the development of websites, and listservs would be helpful.   
  5. We informed the community of the technologies and sought feedback on the instrument mix or technologies that should be considered for future development for seafloor geodesy. These were the primary activities associated with the initial workshop, and included plenary presentations during the meeting itself, as well as a series of pre-meeting webinars, the development of community white-papers, and the formation of a website.  The website, www.seafloorgeodesy.org, now serves as a clearinghouse for information on community activities, and includes meeting announcements, workshop reports, a mechanism for signing up for a newly formed community listserv, and information and updates on community experiments.  

Given the feedback from the first workshop, we were able to hold a second, more-focused workshop to contain the US research community interests in a subduction-zone experiment in the region highlighted as most important in the first workshop.  The "Workshop on the Alaska and Cascadia Seafloor Geodetic Community Experiment" was held in April 2022. Recommendations:

  1. Aim to achieve four specific science goals: (1) understand variations in megathrust coupling along-strike, (2) identify megathrust locking very near the trench where tsunami earthquakes rupture, (3) characterize aseismic fault slip associated with earthquakes, and (4) constrain transient deformation following major earthquakes.
  2. Deploy up to 12 Seafloor Geodesy Instrument Pool sensors at sites across the near-trench environments offshore Cascadia and Alaska. The consensus was for six to seven sites offshore Cascadia and five to six sites offshore Alaska.
  3. Continue observations at existing GNSS-Acoustic sites along the Cascadia and Alaska.
  4. Develop open-source GNSS-Acoustic processing algorithms.
  5. Training courses are needed to focus on data collection.
  6. Develop an apply-to-sail program for students and early-career scientists.
  7. With international partners, the community needs to establish data standards for seafloor geodetic data. 
  8. The data collected through a community experiment should follow FAIR data principles and an open data policy.
